Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on the Dynamic Interaction of Embodied Human and Machine Intelligence; Marconi State Historic Park, Marshall, California; June 2018

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support an interdisciplinary workshop to study how humans and intelligent machines, such as robots, may behave while physically interacting with each other, in contrast to situations where they only exchange information. These questions will become increasingly important as humans begin to come into frequent physical contact with intelligent machines, such as when navigating shared spaces, riding in or walking near autonomous vehicles, or interacting with caregiving or physical therapy robots.

This workshop will gather experts from cognitive neuroscience, behavioral science, dynamics and control, robotics, optimization, and computer science to define key challenges in analyzing the dynamic behavior of systems of embodied human and machine intelligences. Due to rapidly developing capabilities in machine learning, and wide scale deployment of autonomous and intelligent robotic systems, humans in the near future will regularly find themselves physically interacting with intelligent technology. Such intelligent technology might include home assistance robots, physical therapy robots, autonomous vehicles, and smart buildings. The dynamics of physically coupled of humans and intelligent machines have so far received little study, despite the potential for unexpected behavior.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Humans routinely interact with their physical environments, such as buildings, so much so that they become a natural extension of the nervous system and the body.  There is a significant need from both the basic and applied sciences to understand the synergistic, symbiotic relationship between human agents and their adaptive physical interactions with intelligent environments, including buildings. On the flip side, there is an equivalent need to understand how intelligent environments can adapt to human agents in a variety of contexts. In addition to advances in engineering these intelligent environments, there is a great need to understand human perception, action, and cognition and the mechanisms that contribute to this adaptive behavior. 

Two workshops were held to bring together a group of scientists to help define and fine tune the research agenda for the field of dynamic human machine interaction. These workshops represent two growing themes of activity in the NSF M3X community in partnership with several interdisciplinary scientific communities. 

The first workshop was held in August 2018, at Point Reyes California, as specified in the previous year's report. The theme of this workshop focused on motor control, perception, dynamical systems, robotics and brain-machine interfaces.

The second workshop was held at the University of Southern California's campus in Los Angeles in May 2019. The theme of this workshop was on the dynamic interaction between human and built environments. The workshop catalyzed the creation of a nascent scientific community that engages in the study of human-building interaction at all levels. Broadly conceived, Human Building Interaction (HBI), an emerging field, represents the dynamic interplay of embodied human and machine intelligence, how humans interact, perceive and navigate through natural and built environments, spaces and designs, and how reciprocal actions/influences of humans and buildings on each other change the building behavior as well as the human behavior.

The objective of this workshop was to bring together an interdisciplinary team of scientists and engineers to define the key questions in this emerging field in the context of NSF’s goals of enhancing the future of work at the human-technology frontier. The workshop brought together engineers (civil, mechanical, electrical) with neuroscientists, psychologists, occupational scientists and cognitive scientists. Details of the workshop can be found here: https://www.intelligentenvironments.usc.edu/nsfworkshop
